title: 103_hr1753
content: The Act titled "Democracy in Presidential Debates Act of 1993" defines presidential candidate debates and presidential primary debates. Section 9002 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to define "Presidential primary debate" as a debate before the first primary or caucus where candidates receiving matching funds must participate, and "Presidential candidate debate" as a debate where all nominees for President appear and answer questions on various issues. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section regarding Presidential primary debates. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section specifying additional eligibility requirements for candidates participating in Presidential primary debates. Candidates must agree to participate in at least one debate with specific criteria, held before the first primary or caucus of the election year, and sponsored by a nonpartisan organization. If on December 31 there are 6 or fewer candidates obligated or eligible to debate, there will be 1 debate among them. If there are more than 6 candidates, there will be 2 debates, with each candidate participating in 1 of their choice. Debates must last at least 90 minutes, with 30 minutes for questions and answers. The sponsor must announce the time, location, and format of each debate before the first Monday of January. To be eligible for primary debates, candidates must have qualified for payments under section 9033 by January 1 of the election year. If a candidate who received payments fails to participate in a debate, they must repay the amount received to the Treasury. Sponsoring organizations organizing debates must include qualifying candidates in at least one debate. The table of sections for chapter 96 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to add a new item that meets the criteria in this section. SEC. 9043: Presidential primary debates. Section 9003 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to require Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates to participate in at least 2 debates to be eligible for payments under section 9006. One debate must be held in September before the Presidential election. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to require Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates to participate in debates before the election. Candidates must participate in at least 2 debates, one in September and one in October, with specific criteria for participation. Each debate must last at least 90 minutes and be sponsored by a nonpartisan organization. The debates under this subsection must last at least 90 minutes, with a minimum of 30 minutes for candidate interaction. The sponsor must announce the debate details before the first Monday in September. If a candidate fails to participate and is deemed responsible, they must repay the amount received in public funding. Eligibility criteria for debate participation are also outlined. To participate in general election debates, a candidate must meet criteria such as qualifying for the ballot in at least 40 states and meeting financial qualifications by receiving payments or raising a minimum of $500,000. The sponsoring organization must include all candidates who meet the criteria in the section for general election debates. Section 9032(2)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include initiating petition signature gathering activities for independent or minor party candidates to be placed on the ballot for the general election.
